Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Tailoring the Surface State Conduction in Semiconductor and Topological Insulator Nanowires
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER award is jointly funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) and Condensed Matter Physics Program (CMP), both in the Division of Materials Research.
Technical: Due to the ubiquitously large surface-to-volume ratio of nanomaterials, surface and interface effects are essential to their electronic and optoelectronic properties. The research component of this CAREER award focuses on the fundamental study and control of surface state conduction in nanowires of indium arsenide and bismuth compounds (e.g., bismuth selenide or telluride), two model systems of the conventional III-V semiconductors and the recently discovered topological insulators. In conventional semiconductor nanowires, surface states generally degrade the material's performance and are often undesirable. However, for topological insulators, the topological surface states are the subject of interest for both basic research and potential device applications, and thus should be protected against the bulk states, which have been hindering the progress in the topological surface state research. In this research project, surface functionalization, doping and heterostructured material design are employed experimentally to tailor the surface conduction in semiconductor and topological insulator nanowires. These material and synthetic controls of the surface are further complemented by the conductance and capacitance spectroscopy for the quantitative understanding and evaluation of the surface versus bulk transport in nanowires
Non-technical: Nanowires have become an important material platform in modern nanoelectronics and photonics. Since nanomaterials have very high surface to volume ratio, surface effects could dominate the overall electronic properties and greatly impact the material performance. This CAREER project aims to achieve a comprehensive understanding of and precise control over the electronic surface states in nanowires of either conventional semiconductor or the recently discovered topological insulator materials. The research activities are expected to benefit multiple areas in which nanomaterials are playing an essential role. With this CAREER project, the PI also seeks to establish an education program integrated with the research project at Case Western Reserve University. Both graduate and undergraduate students engage actively in the project and learn state-of-the-art nanoscience and technology. In addition, pre-college students in the Cleveland area are being outreached through collaborations with a local girls' school and an inner city school with 100 percent of students receiving subsidized lunches. These outreach efforts are made to stimulate young students' interest and enthusiasm in pursuing science and technology as a future career. Further education and outreach endeavor of this project includes the development of a layman-level interactive web page and nanoscience course/lecture development related to the research activity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Driven by the rapid development of highly integrated electronics and optoelectronics, the need for designing and understanding new nanoscale materials becomes more and more urgent. When materials become smaller and smaller, they have an increasingly large surface to volume ratio. As a result, the surface could dominate a nanomaterial's overall properties and nanomaterials are ideal for studying novel surface properties. Another important issue to consider in employing nanomaterials in devices is that the quantum mechanical nature of matter, or wave-particle duality, may render the nanomaterial behaving like a low dimensional system for particles (electrons, phonons) moving inside and give rise to effects or properties distinct from bulk.  

This CAREER project has focused on studying nanostructures (nanowires, nanoribbons, nanoplates) made of two categories of materials, III-V semiconductors (e.g. InAs) and V-VI chalcogenide topological insulators (e.g. Bi2Se3, Bi2Te3). InAs is an important semiconductor in the semiconductor industry because of its high electron transport performance. In InAs nanowire devices, we have for the first time shown that the quantum mechanical confinement of electrons (due to electrons' finite wave-length becoming comparable to nanowire's diameter) gives rise to one-dimensional behavior in the nanowire's thermoelectric property and may be used to tailor the thermoelectric efficiency of converting thermal energy into electricity. The large surface to volume ratio of InAs nanowires was also exploited to convert an InAs nanowire transistor into a fluid flow sensor and energy converter to convert fluid flow's mechanical energy into electricity. On the end of studying topological insulator nanomaterials which have conducting surface states due to the material's topological band structure, we have achieved an in-depth understanding of the large linear magneto-resistance in topological insulators and shown that the linear magneto-resistance can be controlled by the degree of porosity or connectivity in films of interconnected Bi2Te3 nanoplates. The understanding and control of large linear magnetoresistance may open up applications of topological insulators, a new class of quantum materials, in magnetic sensors and other related devices. Controlled doping of Bi2Se3 and Bi2Te3 nanoribbons and flakes were also achieved to precisely tune the topological insulator material's electronic behavior.

In addition to these research findings that may result in future technological applications of semiconductor nanowires and topological insulator nanostructures, the project has generated impact in many students at different education levels from postdoctoral to high school. Five female students participated in the project and continued their education or career in science and technology. Research collaborations and exchange with a teaching college in the U.S. and several academic institutions in Taiwan and China were also fostered. These educational outcomes are expected to help to enhance the U.S. workforce in Science and Technologies.
